reviewText: Senso - a film so famous that a remake in 2011 and an opera were made to dwell on its undying glory.  As always with the most notorious movies, there is an enigma to what exactly make them live and shine, outlive all who have done it and still gain new worshipers.  We can at least try to analyze what makes it a cult and golden calf around which there is such a constant dance macabre.It is interesting to research about the literary source of the film, a novella "Senso" by Camillo Boito (a man, just as the author of Anna Karenina and Madame Bovary), written in 1882.  In the book, the character of Livia is one of a lustful, selfish and revengeful female who watches the execution of her lover with the same delight as she experienced in his arms.  It seems to be obvious that Visconti was inspired by a theme of a predatory female destroying a vulnerable, fragile male who desperately tries to fight for his life in society but is finished off by an axe lowered by the lecherous, furious and vengeful Bacchante.This idea gains force in Visconti's later movies, starting with  "Death in Venice" in the threatening figure of the watchful mother, and continuing with crescendo from "Ludwig" through " Conversation Piece" to "L'Innocente", where the destructive female appears in all her horror, equipped with the flawless physical beauty which she uses as weapon to drive the poor man to his ruin.In a sense, "Senso" has shoots of many other obsessions that Visconti expressed later on in the aforementioned films - here we have a hero renamed from the original name in the novel of Remigio Ruz to Franz Mahler, in honor of the composer whose music Visconti adored and used to much acclaim in "Death in Venice".  And it is these obsessions that distinguish his work and turn it into cult status.The obsessive attention to detail resulting in incomparable beauty of cinematography, camera work, leading actor, costumes, decorations, of the places where the films were made, his drive to authenticity and perfection makes his work above compare, and like the pictures of the old masters, more and more valuable as we move further in the Braver Newer World of art.For all those reasons, I have become a zealot of Visconti decades ago, and I watch his movies, including "Senso", from time to time, as one goes to a museum to delight in a beloved masterpiece.  But the reason to finally write a review was an amazing coincidence when visiting Veneto region the last autumn; the goal was to see as many as possible Palladian villas, and what a surprise I had when after arriving in Villa Godi-Malinverni, I learned that "Senso" was filmed there!  These were the episodes when Livia leaves Venice for her country villa; and it is in the villa that Franz breaks into her bedroom, alarming dogs and causing the famous uproar.  It was curious to observe that the Villa was quite far from Venice - it is between Bassano del Grappa and Vicenza, and in 1882 it would probably take days to reach it!The Villa is today even more amazing - in the film one can hardly notice the frescoes, and the garden in front in 1954 was not as luxurious as it is now, although in the timeline of the story it was probably even more opulent than today - with roses, camellias and other magical plants that perfume the air in warm September sun...Visconti has grown up in palaces and villas like Villa Godi-Malinverni; certainly the aristocratic rich friends and relatives of his family had similar properties.  This villa is occupied today by a private owner, and the neighboring Villa Poiano is today a country retreat of a certain countess - just like Livia, only that today's countess lives in Milano, not in Venice.  Since Visconti was a habitue in such villas and palaces like the one rented in Palermo for "Il Gattopardo" shooting, he knew intimately how to furnish the place and make it look the way it should be.  This adds an irreplaceable allure to all his films which exude glamor and elegance.The story of the film "Senso" is forever captivating, as sex and violence always are.  Love, betrayal, hate - all the titillating subjects that entertain humanity.  Perhaps I watched this movie so many times that this time I lost some sensitivity to "Senso" the story.  But some side observations emerged:1.  The character of Fritz Mahler, presented unsympathetically in 19th century morality as a as coward who does not wish to fight in a war occupies a central place in 20th century as an existentialist figure.  His moral dillema of an individual having to sacrifice his life on the altar of the rich and powerful cannot be more modern even today.  Ironically, Austria's empire disintegrated shortly after the film's events were taking place, making his doubts and views prophetic.2. The reunification of Italy - one would ask the same question today as it was asked in Garibaldi's times - was it such a good idea?  As of today, it seems clear that the North Italy is a true beneficiary, while the South continues to sink, justly confirming Il Gattopardo's pessimism.  Also the theme of Southern migrants has been duly explored in "Rocco and his brothers", revealing rejection of the South by the North.  Perhaps the South would indeed fare better if it would be independent from the authority of Turin and Milan.  And the WWII destruction of Italy could have been much less severe as Mussolini dragged the whole country into the inferno.  Had Italy remained fragmented as it was in middle ages, for example, cities like Treviso or Livorno could have survived intact.3. After being to numerous cities and towns in Italy,  one cannot fail to notice that major roads, streets and squares bear all the same names - Piazza Garibaldi, Corso Cavour, Via Mazzini, etc.  We owe this destruction of history to the propaganda of the reunification benefits which with passage of time seem more and more dubious.Such thoughts were provoked by a film that was supposedly not designed to do so! However, as with any genius work of art, it lives its own life and inspires the viewer to the most unexpected ideas.  I also attach some current images  of Villa Godi-Malinverni.This film is simply extraordinary, as the opera "Il Trovatore", city of Venice, Palladian villas, human passions...  A must for all times.

reviewText: Typically superb package from Criterion for Visconti's peerless Italian classic... Operatic in its melodramatic construction, sumptiously filmed, and vividly acted, it features the director at the height of his powers, which would reach the pinnacle of their achievement in period mode with THE LEOPARD/IL GATTOPARDO... Includes the new restoration of the Italian original, a rarely seen English language version - THE WANTON COUNTESS, and several very salient documentaries as extras, most notably MAN OF THREE WORLDS: LUCHINO VISCONTI from the BBC in 1966...

reviewText: Criterion has made lots of people very happy with this comprehensive release of Luchino Visconti's 1954 masterpiece SENSO.  Loosely based on Camillo Boito's novella of the same name, SENSO is the story of a doomed love affair, set during the turmoil of Austria-occupied Italy in 1866.During a performance of "Il trovatore" at La Fenice, the Countess Livia (Alida Valli) meets Austrian officer Franz Mahler (Farley Granger).  The two fall into a torrid love affair, which is made all the more scandalous because of their individual loyalties.  When Franz begs Livia to give him the money he needs in order to bribe certain officials and exit the army, Livia reluctantly hands over the Italian partisan funds that were entrusted to her by her cousin, exiled because of his actions in trying to undermine the Austrian army.  When she later receives a rather strange letter from Franz, Livia follows him back to Verona, where her ever-crumbling sanity reaches the breaking point...SENSO is a delicate piece which borders on the operatic.  It's not by coincidence that shortly after this film, Luchino Visconti became one of the most prolific opera directors in Europe.  Leading actors Alida Valli and Farley Granger both deliver superb performances, but the star of SENSO is undoubtedly the bewitching Ms Valli, who in her performance as the Countess Livia, is almost an opera heroine in real-life.Lush in it's design and photography, it's strange to think that SENSO sadly didn't make much of an impression during it's original release in 1954.  Critics felt that Luchino Visconti was "betraying" his neo-realist attitudes, not quite realising that in SENSO he beautifully blended neo-realism with theatrical grandeur, therefore creating a whole new genre of filmmaking.Criterion's two-disc DVD package includes the seldom-seen English language dub of SENSO entitled "The Wanton Countess", which is significantly shorter than the original Italian cut.  The English dub is noteworthy in that both Farley Granger and Alida Valli's voices can finally be heard.  The print of "The Wanton Countess", supplied by Harvard University, isn't in the best shape, with lots of jumps and splices; Aldo Graziati's colour photography is dulled considerably with the film sadly looking like it's been soaked in brown tea.  Rest assured that the original Italian cut of SENSO looks crisp and beautiful by comparison.
summary: operatic drama a treat for fans

reviewText: Overall, Senso is worth watching, simply because it is well made fluff that, while not deep nor great, represents an important milestone in European cinema. There are no good, nice, nor even likable characters, but, on a rudimentary level, one can sense the motives of the two leads, even if neither is a character of depth. Thus the film, at least, has a narrative integrity that many melodramas lack, and, once Mahler betrays Livia, it is inevitable that she will damn him. Its use of red herrings and feints of narrative and character development is well done: such as when Livia is told, upon the Count's wanting to leave Venice, that a man came to call on her, she assumes it is Mahler, is followed by the Count, and, when confronted, confesses to having a lover, only to find out the man who called was Ussoni. The Count thereby assumes her revelation of a lover was a ruse to protect Ussoni, whom the Count has little use nor respect for. It's these sorts of moments that lift Senso above run of the mill melodrama, albeit, like Gone With The Wind, not far enough into real drama. If only Visconti had been able to graft a small bit of his working class affinities by showing a bit more of the struggles of the Italian Resistance, Senso may have hurdled that bar. Sans that, Senso lives up to its titular billing, as but a sensual comfort. And all can use a bit of that from time to time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There's plenty wrong with this movie (over-scored and -written, languidly paced, theatrically acted, at times unconvincingly dubbed; the "restored" transfer lacks sharpness and detail, with colors often looking like they've been filtered through wax-paper, etc. But it remains an important, often beautiful film, with some breathtaking interior and exterior shots. A film to admire, if not love.On watching it a second time I've discovered visual splendors I hadn't appreciated the first time. The film has more dimensions--and chapters--than I remembered. Some rather spectacular scenes of battle. The use of color is stunning. Though I still find the over-use of Bruckner's Seventh unforgivable. A form of cheating. Valli's melodramatic emoting, for all its fervor, does not really give me a sense of what this woman is about, acting as much as a mask as a manifestation of interiority.Dubbed films are alienating, so that's one huge barrier. Having to read the subtitles makes it even worse. And yet I can't argue with those who maintain Senso is, despite its shortcomings, a masterful film. But it is a difficult work to get into and may require several viewings. It's "operatic": broad, exaggerated, and aesthetically heightened. The spaces are grand and sublime in a way wide-screen would not have been able to effect. They have all-imprtant height, not just width. Visually and as a completely realized 'authentic' period piece it is a work of genius. But its acting is conventional and a bit on the ripe side, as if Visconti felt he needed to exaggerate to make an impression. Granted, that reflects both his background in the theater and film conventions of the day. But those of us who admire subtlety can't help but feel disappointed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Politically the most interesting thing about the film is how little the Italian aristocrats seem to care about Italian independence and how little the Austrian soldiers seem to care about empire building. Such nationalist ideals are of little interest to those that belong to a class that has no political ideals and is only interested in politics insofar as they can be of service to personal ambition/aristocratic privilege. What's really at stake here, and what is really at stake in his later and much greater film, The Leopard, is not the Italian nation, but the continued relevance of the aristocracy itself.Visconti is interested in marking that transition between the old world and the new. He obviously favors the old world over the new but he sees faults in both worlds. To him the aristocracy has not kept pace with the world and it has failed to see that a new world is about to be born; but at the same time those zealous democrats that are trying to bring about a new world order fail to see that cynicism and corruption will not vanish with the passing of the aristocracy.Even though the films themes are big, the story focuses on two representative types: the Contessa Serpieri and the Austrian officer Franz Mahler. Fittingly they meet at the opera (fittingly because opera like Italian history is a clash of large passions). The opera house is like an historical stage, and the players are both the Italian aristocrats who sit idly by and the Austrian occupiers who feel it is only a matter of time until Italy becomes part of their own growing empire. Tensions exist between the Italians and their Austrian occupiers but the Italians seem to care less about Italian unity & independence than about their own manhood. The Contessa feels enlivened and excited by all the male posturing; for her Italian independence which gets the men so riled up is a turn-on, but so is the glamor and power of the Austrian army which seems more like an army of cultured aristocrats than of common foot soldiers. In the opera house emotion runs high, and it appears that what is being fought for are large ideals. What is hidden from view are the lies and deceit and cowardice that really drive most men and women.Senso is an expose of politics, but its also an expose of love. Visconti sees both as beginning with great ideals and ending in disillusion. If the film does not succeed at the same level as The Leopard, it is because the only character that seems to believe in anything greater than his own selfish gain is the Contessa's cousin, the patriot Roberto. But Roberto's such an exaggerated version of a do-gooder patriot that we see him as being perhaps the most delusional of all---for anyone who knows their history would know that ideals do not last long in the world of Italian politics.What is maybe a little unbelievable is the lengths that the Contessa will go to be with her Franz who is so obviously undeserving of her adoration. Franz gives her every clue that any woman would need to figure out that he is a shallow wastrel and philanderer, but the Contessa, madly in love/lust, ignores them all.The best scene of the film is the final showdown in Franz's bachelor loft/den of vice. In fact the beautiful actress who plays his hired lover was featured on the cover of the VHS version of this film that I saw years ago (when it was called The Wanton Countess). The prostitutes matter of fact handling of other people's vices/delusions/tantrums is a striking contrast to the way the Contessa and Franz handle their own epic disappointment in life and in themselves. In contrast to the defeated Contessa and Franz, the prostitute seems almost pure. She is the true herald of the new age, she is someone who lives without illusions. She is beautiful, but she represents an empty kind of beauty, a vulgar kind of beauty--the kind of beauty Visconti detests more than he detests his corrupt aristocrats. The aristocrats at least had grandeur.Not as great as the earlier Ossessione or the later Leopard, but probably my third favorite Visconti film.
summary: Angels of History, Demons of Love

reviewText: What a great film. Altough Farley Granger seems out of place, I can't recommend this enough for fans of Italian cinema. Everyone is dubbed, of course, and the Criterion Blu-ray looks fantastic except for a washed out scene at the very end. The sound is mono, but sufficient for the well-placed chunks of Bruckner's 7th symphony which really make this something special. Don't watch The Wanton Countess bonus feature- after seeing the original Italian you won't want to anyway. Get it....
summary: Alida Valli at her most passionate....

reviewText: The Leopard - Criterion CollectionLe Notti Bianche (White Nights) - Criterion CollectionYesterday, Today And Tomorrow (Remastered Edition)Boccaccio '70 (Remastered Edition)I find it humorous that a distributor like Criterion would go to such lengths to collect the best film elements and sink even more money into predominantly superfluous video extras only to run with the lamest DVD cover I've seen this side of straight-to-video Mexican dance-comedies from the 1980s. It looks like they used a false, three-color retouch on a black and white photo-novella image. This is an important (if flawed) film and yet the box art makes it look like an Italian "Dirty Dancing" rip-off. I'll be amazed if it ships 10,000 units based on that cover graphic. Even the Russian bootleg had a better cover! Somebody fire the marketing staff!Gaffs like this make me miss video labels like NoShame, whose Boccaccio 70 and Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow were flawless and packaged to capitalize on the arthouse royalty that contributed to their excellence.I know that this transfer was done for the Venice Film Festival by conservation-minded contributors so this particular print of Senso is likely to be the ultimate print of the film, and not lackluster like many of the overrated Criterion releases have been in the past. Which is ever more the shame that the same care that went into making the film, then restoring it wasn't put into packaging it.Usually these mistakes are made when sales and marketing aren't paying enough attention to what production is doing, and looking at the ramped up release schedule that they've got going at Criterion, it's no wonder. They'd be better off slowing down and getting back to the aesthetic that established their brand name back in the Laserdisc era -not jamming as much product down the pipeline as possible. In the video business, multi-tasking is code for doing too much too poorly. Case in point: Senso.The film itself is good. Not great. Not Excellent. Just good. The casting resulted from the dropouts of intended leads Ingrid Bergman and Marlon Brando, and with that cast, this film might have been an actual classic rather than a pretty good film in the resume of a great director. "Death in Venice" this isn't. Like many Criterion releases, it contains the types of extras that seem to exist solely to justify a higher price than you should reasonably pay for a title with as little appeal as this: a video essay by Peter Cowie, two documentaries that interview (mostly) people whose involvement was very little: assistant directors, costumers, relatives of the filmmakers. It does include the alternate English language cut of the film, emphasis on "cut," which is neat to see, but barely helps justify the extra ten bucks.But let's face it: if this didn't have Criterion Collection written on the spine, this DVD would be $9.99, and while that might not allow justify the inclusion of a documentary about a new opera based on this material, you wouldn't miss it. The BBC doc "Man of Three Worlds" is excellent, however, and along with the alternate cut make this a compelling purchase if you are a fan of Visconti's work. Truth be told, if you have a particular fondness for this film, you can do no better than this release of it, but if you are a budget-minded consumer of arthouse film, I'd recommend renting it rather than buying. Why? You'll only watch it once, you won't care for most of the extras, and you can put that cash you just saved towards the Criterion Collection releases of The Leopard or Le Notti Bianchi instead.
summary: Fully remastered -and that's the best cover they could design?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Criterion gives us another opulent masterpiece from Luchino Visconti to follow their splendid release of IL GATTOPARDO (THE LEOPARD).  The blu-ray has a rich, Technicolor density that beautifully captures the evocative, lush location photography by Guiseppe Rottuno, and is another splendid restoration of classic Italian cinema, under the supervision of Rottuno and Martin Scorsese.SENSO is expressionistic filmmaking by a master, full of homoerotic tension in the guise of deranged, heterosexual passion.  There is both the original Italian and the rarely-seen, English language version (THE WANTON COUNTESS) to savor here, along with some insightful extras about Verdi, Visconti and the making of the film.A remarkable film can now be appreciated in a high-quality US release for home screenings.

reviewText: When you consider this was made in 1954, it blows your mind. All of Visconti's films (except Leopard) were brilliant, but this, Death in Venice, Rocco, and The Damned are his finest. Hallmarks of Visconti's genius are his use of intense and exceptional classical music to comment on the screen action; gorgeous sets and opulent costumes; and a tragic sense of life. He loves beautiful people, and as we know, was gay. WHY he chose Farley Granger as the decadent hunk I am at a loss to guess. Granger is ordinary, almost ugly, and definitely does not look Austrian. He is the one weak link in this masterpiece. With all the beautiful guys available at the time, and given that Visconti was gay, why did he cast this runty, grade-B actor? Alida Valli is gorgeous, and serves well as a fragile woman seeking romantic love... Would she really fall for such an ordinary looking loser? It is interesting to compare this film about a woman's desperate love, with the novels Madame Bovary and Anna Karenina. Unlike those heroines, Livia gets her swift revenge.The film opens at the Teatro La Fenice in Venice, where we attend the fourth act of Il Trovatore, swarming with the wealthy and beauteous. Gorgeous singing and sets. Thereafter, themes from Bruckner's Seventh Symphony waft through the remainder of the film, echoing the ambivalent feelings of the heroine. She had a premonition ("Senso" of the title) that she will be betrayed by this fatuous rogue. And she is not disappointed, whereupon, like any woman scorned, she exacts revenge. Substantive, moving, brilliant and way ahead of its time.As an afterword, two of Visconti's bedfellows were Franco Zeffirelli (also gay), and Helmut Berger, star of The Damned. Granger was friends with Leonard Bernstein and Aaron Copeland, Roddy McDowell and Arthur Laurents.
summary: A Masterpiece Similar to Children of Paradise

reviewText: I've heard of this for eons, but it has been very difficult to see. It occasionally shows up on TCM, but the print always looks horrible. It is always praised as a major Technicolor achievement, so I wanted the best looking version i could get. This is a major improvement, but I fear, still isn't as vivid and dazzling as it probably was in '55 or whenever. It was released in Italy, then re-edited and messed up for American release. This is supposedly the original, complete film, and looking as close to full saturation as is possible. It's impressive, but not up to the best of domestic three strip.The film itself is an epic tale of a woman's obsession with Farley Granger, a military rake from the enemy camp who seduces and abandons her.  It's plenty absurd, but the star power is irresistable. There is a commentary track, and also the American version is included. But after going through the normal film, and the commentary, I didn't want to sit through it again. But I a m sort of looking forward to seeing what it looks like. Apparently, the actual Granger audio track is used here, so we actually hear him rather than the dubbed in Italian version shown in Italy. But it's cut down and supposedly trashed.Still,, a great package of Criterion excess that is a great wallow in a major world film that still remains somewhat elusive.
Title: N/A

reviewText: 1866 Venice. The Italians are organized to reclaim the province from the Austrian empire. Such is the backdrop for this melodrama. The strength of this film is not in the 'love affair' plot, but in Visconti's operatic direction and unsurpassed ability to recreate history. The undertone is decidedly bittersweet because a way of life, with its beauty, elegance and decadence, is absorbed by history with the birth of a new nation.(An aside, the U.S. audience is viewing an edited version; most films play better when released in accordance to the artist's vision).
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are 2 reasons I wanted to finally see this film: (A) a friend of mine had been going on and on about it; and (B) after the death of Farley Granger, my interest was piqued even more.  However, as much as I wanted to--I could not love this film.  Nor is it one I care / need to watch again.  And after having seen "Ossessione", "Death in Venice", and now "Senso"--I'm still not a fan of Luchino Visconti.  Whereas "Sunset Boulevard" is a tragedy that I have seen many times, and that I can enjoy each time I watch it again--"Senso" falls short of the complete filmic experience for me.  To its credit, were I to see "Senso" again, the pros are as follows: (1) Alida Valli gives an outstanding performance, blending hysteria, heartbreak, confusion, disillusionment, agony.  This is clearly her film and she is its star; although Farley Granger also gives a solid performance, his lines are dubbed by an Italian actor.  (2) Alida Valli's costumes are sensational.  (3) The score is beautiful, particularly the music of Anton Bruckner as it is used in the picture.  (4) The story in this film, more than the various visual components, is what defines it and gives it momentum.  The cons are: (1) I'm not drawn to period pieces and historical dramas; (2) This particular time period in history holds no interest for me; (3)  Although I know this is a tragedy, there is nothing transcendent or inspiring in this film (besides the music).  In spite of my objections, and in the spirit of objectivity: (1) I enjoyed the extras / supplemental material on both DVDs 1 and 2.  If one is interested in finding out more about Visconti, about whom I knew little (-IE- I didn't know that Visconti also directed opera; that influence is noticeable in the style in which "Senso" was executed), here is a good place to start.  I watched and enjoyed all of that supplemental material, with the exception of the "rarely seen English-language version of the film", as I know Italian well enough to have understood most of "Senso" even without subtitles.Stephen C. Bird, Author of "Hideous Exuberance"
summary: Good Film--Though Not Great--Superb Lead Actress & Excellent Score
